Fig 23 Review The development in aqueous lithium-ion batteries Duan Bin Yunping Wen Yonggang Wang Yongyao Xia ⁎ Department of Chemistry and Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Institute of New Energy, Fudan University, Shanghai 200433, China Department of Chemistry and Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials Institute of New Energy Fudan University Shanghai 200433 China ⁎ Corresponding author. To meet the growing energy demands, it is urgent for us to construct grid-scale energy storage system than can connect sustainable energy resources. Aqueous Li-ion batteries (ALIBs) have been widely investigated to become the most promising stationary power sources for sustainable energy such as wind and solar power. It is believed that advantages of ALIBs will overcome the limitations of the traditional organic lithium battery in virtue of the safety and environmentally friendly aqueous electrolyte. In the past decades, plentiful works have been devoted to enhance the performance of different types of ALIBs. In this review, we discuss the development of cathode, anode and electrolyte for acquiring the desired electrochemical performance of ALIBs. Also, the main challenges and outlook in this field are briefly discussed. Graphical abstract Compared to traditional non-aqueous batteries, aqueous Li-ion battery (ALIB) is considered as one of the most promising stationary power sources for sustainable energies due to their highly safe and environment-friendly performance. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Li-ion batteries Aqueous electrolyte Cathode Anode Electrochemical performance 1 Introduction Due to the formidable sustainability challenges, there are numerous needs for significant research in various disciplines, including the field of electrochemical energy storage derived from solar, wind and tidal power [1,2]. Substantial progress in battery technology is essential if we need to succeed in an energy transition towards a more carbon-neutral society. Since its commercialization in 1990, a rechargeable lithium ion (Li-ion) battery with organic electrolytes possess a lot of advantages of high energy density and lighter weight, making it possible to become an alternative energy source for large-scale applications in electricity storage stations, electric vehicles, and other portable electric devices [3–4]. However, the use of flammable and toxic organic electrolytes still hinders their wide application. Since development of the first aqueous Li-ion battery (ALIB) by Dahn's group in 1994, number of efforts have devoted on ALIBs in order to replace the flammable organic solvent with a more green and safe aqueous-base electrolyte, theoretically providing an average operating voltage of 1.5 V, with energy density (75 Wh kg−1) larger than the Pb-acid batteries (75 Wh kg−1) [5–7]. Nevertheless, the cycling of VO2/LiMn2O4 aqueous lithium battery was very poor. In spired by the pioneer work, LiV3O8/LiNi0.81Co0.19O2, LiV3O8/LiCoO2, TiP2O7/LiMn2O4, and LiTi2(PO4)3/LiMn2O4 aqueous lithium-ion batteries have also been reported in the 2000s [8–10]. Similar to the VO2/LiMn2O4 system, the cyclability of the problem was not fundamentally resolved. In the later 2007s, our group made a kind of ALRBs with superior cycling stability by combining LiMn2O4 cathode and Nasicon-type LiTi2(PO4)3 in 1 M Li2SO4 aqueous solution [11]. Subsequently, our group found that the LiTi2(PO4)3 anode in a discharged state can react with water and oxygen, resulting in capacity fading upon cycling. By eliminating oxygen, adjusting the pH values of the electrolyte and using carbon-coated electrode materials, LiTi2(PO4)3/Li2SO4/LiFePO4 ALIB exhibited excellent stability with capacity retention over 90% after 1000 cycles. ALIBs, are the promising alternatives for large-scale applications, can address several challenges related to conventional Li-ion batteries. Firstly, it can replace highly toxic and flammable organic solvent. Secondly, the easy-to-use conditions and lower cost of electrolyte solvent than conventional Li-ion batteries is also an important progress. Finally, the ionic conductivity of the aqueous electrolyte is higher than those of organic electrolytes by two orders of magnitude, resulting in high round-trip efficiency and energy density even with bulky and scalable electrodes [12]. Despite the identical mechanism of ALIBs to that of conventional organic battery, the electrochemical reaction of Li+ extraction/insertion in aqueous electrolyte is more complicated, thereby leading to a great influence on the selectivity of electrode materials. In aqueous solution, many side reactions from the O2 and water involved, including the H2/O2 evolution reaction, and proton co-intercalation parallel to lithium ion intercalation, obviously affect the coulombic efficiency and cycling life of electrode systems. Therefore, the redox potential of Li+ extraction/insertion should be within or near the electrolysis potentials of water. Over the past decade, a number of ALIBs employing various types of electrode materials have been explored to acquire better electrochemical performance batteries. In this review, we present an overview of selected developments in the area of electrodes (both cathodes and anodes) and electrolyte materials for ALIB systems in the past few years. Mn-based oxides, layered lithium oxides and polyanionic compounds are extensively considered as the alternative cathode materials, and LiTi2(PO4), TiP2O7 and vanadium oxides are exploited as anode materials ALIBs. In addition, the challenges and outlook for future ARLBs are also discussed. 2 Electrodes for aqueous lithium ion batteries 2.1 Cathode materials 2.1.1 Mn-based oxides Since the development of the ALIB by Dahn's group in 1994, VO2 anode and LiMn2O4 cathode, numerous aqueous lithium-ion cathode materials have been explored. Among various cathode materials explored so far, spinel LiMn2O4 is the most widely researched aqueous cathode material. Subsequently, ALIBS, fabricated with spinel Li2Mn4O9 as the anode and LiMn2O4 as cathode in 6 M LiNO3 solution, can deliver ∼100 mAh g−1 capacity at an average voltage of 1–1.1 V [13]. In 2007, Nakayama et al. investigated the electrochemical properties of LiMn2O4 thin film electrode in aqueous solution. The cyclic voltammograms of the film electrode conducted in aqueous solution were similar to the organic system, two identical coupled current peaks were observed, corresponding to the lithium-ion insertion/extraction reaction, as shown in Fig. 1 (a) and (b) [14]. Also, the previous work reported by Eftekhari et al. has shown that the LiMn2O4 electrode is electrochemically stable in aqueous medium during potential cycling. In 2009, Tian and Yuan prepared nanostructured spinel LiMn2O4 material via a room-temperature solid-state grinding reaction [15]. Electrochemical measurements of the LiMn2O4 were conducted in different concentrated solutions, 1 M, 5 M and 9 M LiNO3 with pH value of 5.71, 5.56 and 5.34, respectively. They have found that, the peak potentials obviously shifted positively with increasing concentration of LiNO3, but the two redox couples were distinct and current increased markedly in 5 M LiNO3, which may indicate better reversibility of the electrode reaction (Fig. 1(c)). Moreover, the electrode in 5 M LiNO3 solution exhibited the best cycling stability with capacity retention of 71.2% after 600 cycles (Fig. 1(d)). Driven by the unsatisfactory cycling of LiMn2O4 material, Qu et al. reported porous LiMn2O4 consisting of nanograins as aqueous cathode material for ALIBs [16]. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), the porous LiMn2O4 exhibits excellent rate behavior as compared to solid LiMn2O4, a discharge capacity of approximately 108 mAh g−1 was obtained at 5 A g−1, and up to 90.0 mAh g−1 was maintained at 10 A g−1. More importantly, Fig. 2(b) shows better cycling stability of porous LiMn2O4 measured at 1 A g−1, which can retain 93% capacity retention after 10,000 cycle, and whereas the discharge capacity of the solid LiMn2O4 electrode decreases rapidly in the first 2000 cycles. In addition, some efforts have been devoted to doping metal ions to the LiMn2O4 crystal to modify the structural integrity. In the Yuan's work, Al-doped LiAl x Mn2 − x O4 samples with different dopant contents were prepared by calcining at different temperatures for different calcination times [17]. It was found in Fig. 3 (a), the LiAl0.1Mn1.9O4 calcined at 800 °C exhibits two distinct couple peaks like that of the ordinary LiMn2O4, which can be ascribed to the high crystallinity of the 800 °C derived material. Further cycle performances concluded that the LiAl0.1Mn1.9O4 derived from 12 h calcination remained higher capacity retentions of 75.6% after 8000 cycles even though it did not exhibit the highest initial specific capacity, as shown in Fig. 3(b). Similarly, Cvjeticanin et al. have also prepared LiCr0.15Mn1.85O4 by a rapid glycine-nitrate method, which displayed delivered more stable cyclability as compared to the undoped LiMn2O4 (Fig. 3(c)). These improvements in stability may be attributed to the depressed Jahn–Teller distortion and stabilization of the octahedral sites [18]. Subsequently, Stojkovic et al. have investigated the influence of vinylene carbonate addition to aqueous electrolyte on the performance of doped LiCr0.15Mn1.85O4 material [7]. It was found that vinylene carbonate can promote the stability of LiCr0.15Mn1.85O4 in aqueous electrolyte (Fig. 3(d)). The vinylene carbonate additive produced a stable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer on electrode materials, which can prevent water molecules from penetrating into aqueous electrodes [19–21]. 2.1.2 Layered lithium oxides Since layered LiCoO2 has made huge commercial application as cathode materials in conventional LIBs, it has also been demonstrated in aqueous batteries. For example, in our previous work, we have studied the electrochemical behavior of LiCoO2 in 1 M Li2SO4 electrolyte solution with various pH from 7 to 13 [22]. We have found that the Li-ion intercalation in the host LiCoO2 is not stable in the electrolyte below pH 9, which is different from the case of LiMn2O4, but it would be stable over pH 11, as shown in Fig. 4 . The chemical instability in the low-pH electrolyte solutions may be due to the intercalation of H+. Our further study showed that, a considerable number of H+ ions at low pH can be transported into the cathode to replace the Li+ ions in aqueous electrolyte solution [23]. These H+ ions are intercalated into the Li x CoO2 cathode, which can covalently be bonded to the oxygen ions, thereby weakening the stability of the cathode. However, Cui and co-workers investigated the performance of LiCoO2 in an aqueous electrolyte containing 5 M LiNO3 at pH value of 7 [24]. It is interesting to see that the efficiency increased to very high values after the first few years, and the measured capacity changed very small after 90 cycle, which is inconsistent with our previous reports (Fig. 5 ). They explained that the impressive cycling behavior of LiCoO2 was attributed to the fast kinetics of 5 M LiNO3 solution. It can be assumed that the Li-ion concentration should affect the competition between Li-ion intercalation and proton co-intercalation. Another layer oxide electrode, LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2, was also examined in different pH aqueous solutions by our group. Similarly, the optimal pH value for the stable Li-ion intercalation of the LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2 electrode should be between 11 and 13 [22]. Mahesh et al. have also observed that LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2 electrode exhibited a pair of reversible redox peaks in 5 M LiNO3 solution [25]. A typical cell using LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2 cathode and LiTi2(PO4)3 anode achieved an average output voltage of 1.0 V with a specific capacity of 84 mAh g−1. Shivashankaraiah et al. introduced polypyrrole as a coating for LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2, coupled with LiV3O8 anode in 5 M LiNO3 solution to form the full cell. This coated LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2 electrode material delivered an initial discharge capacity of 70 mAh g−1 and retained a capacity of 55 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles [26]. 2.1.3 Polyanionic compounds Olivine LiFePO4, which is commonly used in the conventional LIBs, has been investigated as a cathode material in ALIBs. In 2006, Manickam et al. have also studied the Li+ deinsertion/insertion of the LiFePO4 in aqueous electrolyte [27]. It was found that the oxidation of LiFePO4 to FePO4 in LiOH electrolyte was not fully reversible. The presence of metal ions in the solution may initiate the precipitation of oxide compounds, and it can form a mixture of LiFePO4 and Fe3O4 after losing water molecule. Our previous work further indicated that both high OH− and high dissolved O2 contents can cause rapid capacity fading of LiFePO4 [28]. It has been proven in TEM images that, floccules were observed on the surface of LiFePO4 in the presence of O2, whereas the impurities were disappeared in the absence of O2 (Fig. 6 ). To develop highly stable electrode materials, carbon coating is the most widely adopted technique to improve the cycling performance in aqueous electrolyte as well as proof the proposed fading mechanism. In another related work, we prepared carbon-coated LiFePO4 and LiTi2(PO4)3 by chemical vapor decomposition method, which showed significant improvement in the cycling stability [29]. Most recently, LiFePO4/C composites, prepared by Zhao et al., were used as cathode material for ALIBs by coupling with LiV3O8 anode in 9 M LiNO3 solution [30], and the electrochemical performance of the LiFePO4/C//LiV3O8 cell was presented in Fig. 7 (a). This ALIB can achieve a capacity of 88.7 mAh g−1 at 10 C-rate after 100 cycles without dissolved oxygen shown in Fig. 7(b). In addition, Sauvage et al. studied the influence of the nature of solvent on the electrochemical properties of LiFePO4 thin films in 1 M LiNO3 aqueous electrolyte, in which the same electrochemical behavior of LiFePO4 was obtained as that in nonaqueous electrolyte [31]. Liu et al. have synthesized CeO2-modified LiFePO4 cathode, which was compared to the pristine LiFePO4 electrode [32]. It was concluded that 2 wt% CeO2-modified LiFePO4 cathode had the higher reversibility and DLi + values. Other polyanions such as LiMnPO4 and LiNiPO4 were gradually reported for ALIBs by some researchers. For example, Manjunatha et al. firstly studied the electrochemical behavior of LiMnPO4 in saturated LiOH solution and displayed a reversible two-phase reaction between LiMnPO4 and MnPO4 [33]. Another study of the electrochemical behavior of LiMnPO4 in different aqueous electrolytes was reported by Manjunatha et al. [34]. Like the LiCoO2, LiMnPO4 was found to undergo proton insertion at lower concentrations of electrolyte, as shown in Fig. 8 (a). The full cell based on LiTi2(PO4)3/5 M LiNO3/LiMnPO4 presented a discharge capacity of 84 mAh g−1 in the first cycle at an applied current of 0.2 mA cm−2, and it can keep its initial capacity for 50 cycles with good rate capability (Fig. 8(b) and (c)). Interestingly, it was reported that the addition of TiS2 to LiMnPO4 resulted in modification of the electrochemical performance of the cathode electrode by improving lithium-ion insertion/extraction mechanism and suppressing the proton co-insertion reaction [35]. Minakshi et al. have primarily investigated the LiNiPO4 cathode with Sn anode in aqueous LiOH electrolyte [36]. Unlike the solid electrolyte interphase layer that limits the cycling performance, it was found that the chemical stability of Sn in the aqueous LiOH electrolyte is good. As shown in Fig. 9 (a), although the Sn/LiOH/LiNiPO4 cell can reach a charge capacity of 95 mAh g−1, a lower discharge capacity of 55 mAh g−1 was obtained. Similarly, they assembled a novel 1 V battery composed of Zn/ LiCoPO4 using aqueous LiOH electrolyte [37]. Although it exhibited charge/discharge voltages of 1.3 V/0.8 V with a reversible capacity of 80 mAh g−1, the cycling stability only sustained for 25 cycles (Fig. 9(b) and (c)). 2.1.4 Prussian blue analogues Apart from the aforementioned materials, researchers have tried to consider the Prussian blue analogues (PBAs) as potential cathode materials for ALIBs. They have appropriated open framework crystal structures, AxPR(CN)6, which accounts for large interval space that can accommodate the alkali-metal ion with rapid insertion/extraction reaction. In Cui and co-workers, the behavior of bulk CuHCF and NiHCF electrodes was examined in aqueous electrolytes containing Li+, Na+, K+, and NH4+ ions [38]. The PBAs with the coordination of different metal elements exhibit various redox potentials used as a cathode. Both CuHCF and NiHCF showed complex behavior over a wide potential range during the cycling of Li+, and exhibited a discharge capacity nearly to 60 mAh g−1 at 0.83 C (Fig. 10 (a) and (b)). However, they undergo severe capacity loss during cycling with Li+ both CuHCF and NiHCF. Jiang et al. have also prepared graphene modified copper hexacyanoferrate (CuHCF/Gr) as a cathode material for aqueous Li2SO4/Na2SO4 mixed-ion electrolyte battery [39]. The voltage plateaus of CuHCF/Gr in mixed electrolytes were more similar to the ones in Na2SO4 solution. The discharge capacity of CuHCF/Gr in 0.1 M Li2SO4 + 0.4 M Na2SO4 and 0.25 M Li2SO4 + 0.25 M Na2SO4 at 60 C was found to be 86.7 and 85.5%, respectively, which are both higher than in 0.5 M Li2SO4 (83.7%). The higher capacity indicates that the introduction of Na+ into Li2SO4 electrolytes is beneficial to the high rate capability of CuHCF/Gr (Fig. 10(c) and (d)). 2.1.5 Other compounds Trigonal FePO4, similar to LiFePO4 can also be used as a potential cathode for ALIB systems in 2010 [40]. The reaction mechanism of FePO4 in aqueous LiOH electrolyte is the same as that in nonaqueous electrolyte. The results concluded that FePO4 electrode delivered a capacity of 65 mAh g−1 with an average potential of 0.5 V (vs. a Zn anode) in the initial discharge process, whereas the sufficient cycle data were not investigated. In 2012, Sathiyaraj et al. have prepared olivine LiCo1/3Mn1/3Ni1/3PO4 material by sol–gel and solid state methods, and applied in aqueous solution [41]. They found that the LiCo1/3Mn1/3Ni1/3PO4 prepared by sol–gel method can achieve an initial discharge capacity of 45 mAh g−1, and then increased to 60 mAh g−1 over the initial 25 cycles. In contrast, to the one prepared by the solid state method, the material yielded declining capacities of 30 and 20 mAh g−1 in the 10th and 20th cycles, respectively. The improved electrochemical performance of the sol–gel sample proved that the affinity between the particles enhances the intercalation rate in the cathode, indicating that the sol–gel method is better than the solid state method. Another olivine-type cathode for ARLB, LiMn0.05Ni0.05Fe0.9PO4 (3.43 V vs. Li+/Li), was developed by Liu et al. [42]. In Li2SO4 aqueous solution, the LiMn0.05Ni0.05Fe0.9PO4/LiTi2(PO4)3 cell could have a terminal voltage near 1 V, and present the large irreversible capacity in the initial cycles that maybe due to the irreversible capacity of the LiTi2(PO4)3 anode material. However, the cycling performance for this full cell showed that only 70% capacity was maintained after 50 cycles at a current density of 0.2 mA cm−2. In 2009, Stojkovic et al. prepared V2O5 xerogel, and examined its electrochemical properties in saturated LiNO3 aqueous solution [43]. They have found, that the initial discharge capacity was 69 mAh g−1, and kept 89% of its initial value after 100 cycles. The stability of capacity was attributed to the stabilization of the xerogel structure. In comparison to vanadium oxide based crystalline compounds (VO2, LixV2O5, Li x V3O8), V2O5•nH2O xerogel displayed improved Li-intercalation behavior in aqueous LiNO3 solution. 2.2 Anode Material 2.2.1 Vanadium-based compounds In the mid 1990s, VO2 was firstly introduced by Dahn et al. [5] as anode material for aqueous lithium-ion batteries, but it showed serious capacity decay (only 25 cycles). After further investigation, Dahn and co-workers demonstrated that the poor cycle life of ALIB is attributed to the dissolution of electrode materials, the decomposition of water. They have suggested that the capacity fading of the VO2 anode was mainly related to the dissolution of vanadium. Later, C/VO2 core–shell microspheres were prepared by Wang et al. [44] and displayed improved cycling stability with 51% capacity retention after 50 cycles in LiCl aqueous electrolyte. Xu et al. [45] also synthesized VO2 hollow nanourchins from montroseite VOOH using a facile template-free hydrothermal route. Similar to Dahn’s et al. report, the fabricated aqueous VO2/LiMn2O4 cell exhibited poor cycling stability (39.1% capacity retention after 50 cycles). Zhang et al. [46] reported flowerlike micronanostructure VO2 through a hydrothermal route. Combining with LiMn2O4, the cell delivered an initial capacity of 81.3 mAh g−1 and enhanced cycle life with capacity of retention 67% after 50 cycles. Apart from VO2, many V-based compounds have been developed and a number of ARLB systems with improved cycling performance have been reported. Paring with LiNi0.81Co0.19O2 in 1 M Li2SO4 aqueous electrolyte, Toki's group [8] used LiV3O8 as an anode candidate in aqueous lithium-ion battery. However this battery still suffered from the rapid capacity loss with only 25% discharge capacity retained after 100 charge/discharge cycles. The XRD analysis indicate that the structural deterioration of LiV3O8 led to the poor stability. More recently, Wang et al. [9,47] reported ARLB system based on intercalation compounds in which LiV3O8 was used as anode and LiCoO2 as cathode with the output voltage of 1.05 V, 65% and 36% of the discharge capacity could be remained after 40 and 100 cycles (Fig. 11 ). Zhao et al. [48] demonstrated the relatively improved cycling performance of aqueous battery using LiV3O8 anode and LiMn2O4 cathode. But the progress in stability was still inadequate. Concerning the capacity loss mechanism, Chen and co-workers [49,50] reported the stable cyclability in LiMn2O4//Li x V2O5 and LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2//Li x V2O5 by conducting polymer coating on Li x V2O5 anode. Such a protective layer suppressed the dissolving of electrode material and stabilized the electrochemical properties (seen in Fig. 12 ). In the following year, nanostructured LiV3O8 [51–53] was successfully synthesized with elevated capacity and cycling stability. A study by Liang et al. [52] fabricated LiV3O8 nanofibers with exposed {100} facets by electrospinning that, deliver capacity of 105.2 mAh g−1 and good cycling performance with capacity retention of 64.5% for 50 cycles at the lower pH of 5. Zhou et al. [54] prepared the macaroni-like Li1.2V3O8 nanomaterial, achieving the high capacity of 189, 140, and 101 mAh g−1 at 0.1, 0.5, and 1.0 C rate, respectively. Recently, Li0.3V2O5 was employed as an anode material by Bao et al. [55] which has open crystal structure with high ion diffusion and charge transfer properties. The assembled LiCoO2/Li0.3V2O5 full cell delivered first cycle capacity of 182 mAh g−1 at 60 mA g−1, but the cycling performance was still poor. The electrochemical performance of H2V3O8 as anode material for aqueous lithium-ion batteries was firstly investigated by Li et al. [56] in 2010. The prepared single-crystal H2V3O8 nanowires displayed high reversibility with a discharge capacity of 234 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1, nearly twice greater than that of other vanadium compounds. And over 70% capacity was maintained after 50 cycles (Fig. 13 ). In 2012, a novel anode material, Na2V6O16 0.14H2O nanowires was first proposed for ARLBs by Zhou et al. [57]. As shown in Fig. 14 (a), the as-prepared Na2V6O16•0.14 H2O has good reversible lithium-ion insertion/extraction process in neutral Li2SO4. When coupled with Li2MnO4 cathode, the full cell can deliver a discharge capacity if 83 mAh g−1 and exhibit the capacity retention of 77% after 200 charge–discharge process (Fig. 14(b)). 2.2.2 Polyanionic materials Polyanionic materials with open 3D frame structure have been systematically exploited as the most promising anode materials for aqueous lithium-ion batteries because of the extensive advantages like stable voltage plateau, rapid Li-ion diffusion and good structure stability [58]. In 2007, NASICON-type LiTi2(PO4)3 and TiP2O7 were firstly used as anode materials for lithium-ion batteries in aqueous media by Wang et al. [10] LiTi2(PO4)3 and TiP2O7 can be fully used before aqueous electrolyte decomposition with the capacity of 90 mAh g−1 and 80 mAh g−1, respectively (Fig. 15 ). However, both materials suffered from undesirable cycling stability because of their poor electronic conductivity as well as side reactions caused by water and O2. In order to overcome these two problems, Luo et al. [11] combined chemical vapor deposition (CVD) with sol–gel synthesis to form a uniform carbon coating on the surface of LiTi2(PO4)3 particles to prepare carbon-coated LiTi2(PO4)3. The obtained carbon-coated LiTi2(PO4)3 showed excellent cycling performance both in organic and aqueous electrolytes. The full cell LiMn2O4/LiTi2(PO4)3 with 1 M Li2SO4 electrolyte maintained 82% capacity after 200 cycles at a current rate of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 16 ). In the following years, Luo et al. [29] argued that the capacity decay in aqueous lithium-ion batteries are derived from the side reactions from water as well as O2 (Fig. 17 ). Through the elimination of oxygen, the adjustment of the electrolyte pH and the introduction of carbon-coated electrode materials, The capacity retention of the LiTi2(PO4)3/LiFePO4 cell could maintain over 90% after 1000 cycles at 6 C. The Pechini methods were introduced to prepare the LiTi2(PO4)3 by Cui and co-workers [59]. The resulting materials exhibited the discharge capacity of 118 mAh g−1 and good cycling stability with capacity retention of 90% after 100 cycles at a current rate of 0.2 C. To enhance the rate performance of the LiTi2(PO4)3-based ARLBs, various strategies have been developed like carbon coating, metal doping and so on. Huang et al. [60] used a facile method to prepare LiTi2(PO4)3/C nanoporous microplates, which exhibited a high discharge capacity of 121 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C and excellent capacity retention of 94.2% over 100 cycles. At the same time, a number of researches revealed that the surface modification by heteroatoms (e.g. N, B, O) could further improve the electronic conductivity of carbon layers. As reported by Sun et al. [61], LiTi2(PO4)3@nitrogen-doped carbon showed excellent rate performance with the initial capacity of 103 mAh g−1 at 10 C (corresponding to 84% of that at 1 C), and good cycling stability with capacity retention of 91.2% at 0.2 C rate after 100 cycles and 90.4% at 1 C after 400 cycles. More recently, graphene [62] and carbon nanotube [63] were successively incorporated to LiTi2(PO4)3, and excellent cycling stability and high rate performance were also presented. Liu et al. [64] synthesized Sn-doped LiTi2(PO4)3/C composite nanofibers via electrospinning method, which delivered the capacity of 101.7 mA g−1 at 4 A g−1 with capacity retention of 99.5 mA g−1 after 1000 cycles, and its capacity retention can reach 66.2% even at high rate of about 600 C (6 s). Wang and co-workers [65] reported that Na doping can increase lattice volume and enhance the diffusion of lithium ions. The doped material could achieve the optimized electrochemical properties with capacity retention of 90.4% at 2 C after 300 cycles. Considering the negative effects of hydrogen evolution, Wang et al. [66] firstly introduced the F− doping strategy to elevate higher intercalation potential, settling the issues of hydrogen evolution and poor conductivity at the same time (Fig. 18 ). The constructed LiTi2(PO4)2.88F0.12/LiMn2O4 cell reached 2794 W kg−1 and 43.7 Wh kg−1 with long cycling stability and superior rate performance with the capacity retention of 73% at 40 C after 200 cycles (vs 2 C). The possibility of TiP2O7 as anode candidate for ARLBs has long been discounted due to its low capacity, poor cycling performance and terrible rate performance. This material showed extremely poor cycle life in aqueous solution (only 35% of discharge capacity over 25 cycles). Thereafter, many efforts have been made to enhance its electronic conductivity through surface-modification or particle downsizing. Li et al. [67] successfully facilitated the cycling stability of TiP2O7 in aqueous electrolyte through carbon-coating method. The obtained carbon-coated TiP2O7/LiMn2O4 cell delivered the capacities of 86 and 40 mAh g−1 at 0.25 and 10 C, respectively, and showed good cycling stability with capacity retention of 85% after 100 cycles. Wu et al. [68] displayed that C-TiP2O7 composite prepared via the high-energy ball milling, TiP2O7 combined with intimate carbon (graphite) coating had excellent cycling properties in aqueous electrolyte when coupled with LiMn2O4 cathode. After cycled for 150 cycles at 0.5 C, the capacity maintenance is over 91%. In the following years, Zhang et al. [69] fabricated carbon-Fe0.5Ti2(PO4)3(ITP) which can separate the conducting bi-layer on the surface of TiP2O7 particles. The material had the highest capacity up to 115 mAh g−1 and could elevate the rate capability with over 75% capacity retention for 800 cycles at 10 C. Very recently, a study by Wen et al. [70] briefly compared the intercalation potential of TiP2O7, LiTi2(PO4)3 and activated carbon using linear scan voltammetry, further identifying the great potential of TiP2O7 on avoiding hydrogen evolution (Fig. 19 ). Their report introduced expanded graphite (EG) as support medium to prepare TiP2O7/EG nanocomposite, showing good rate capability and cycling stability (up to 1000 cycles) in both half and full cells. 2.2.3 Organic electrode materials and others Organic materials have recently received considerable attention as alternative materials for ALIB systems owing to the advantages of low cost, chemical diversity, probable high energy density. Especially the research on carbonyl group-conjugated compounds with a controllable voltage from 1.5 to 3.0 V (vs. Li+/Li) achieved great progress. In 2008, Wu and co-workers [71] firstly proposed an ARLB based on doping and intercalation using LiMn2O4 cathode and polypyrrole (PPy) anode. The full cell displayed no obvious capacity loss during the first 22 cycles, superior to that of present aqueous battery systems, but the capacity was low (45 mA g−1). Then the ARLB system containing polyaniline (PANI) anode and LiMn2O4 cathode was reported by Liu et al. [72], displaying a capacity of 89.9 mAh g−1 after 150 cycles at 75 mA g−1 with the discharge voltage of 1.1 V. Qin et al. [73] proposed polyimide (PI) as anode materials for ARLB and ARSB, which demonstrated good compatibility and cycle life (Fig. 20 ) in a polyimide/LiCoO2 ARLB with highest specific capacity of 71 mAh g−1 and specific energy of 80 Wh kg−1. In order to mitigate the avoidable side reaction of water and O2, Chen et al. [74] developed a novel ALIB cell using a polyimide (PNTCDA) with both good Li-ion storage capacity and O2 self-elimination property that the lithiated polyimide can be reversibly oxidized by O2 into polyimide itself (Fig. 21 ). The sealed aqueous cell Polyimide-AC/LiMn2O4 in a LiNO3 solution exhibited excellent cycling stability with capacity retention over 95% after 1000 cycles at 2 C, even once overcharged. Subsequently, an aqueous all-organic rechargeable battery was reported by Dong et al. [75] in which polytriphenylamine (PTPAn) cathode paired with PNTCDA anode using a “water-in-salt” electrolyte to suppress the side reactions of water oxidation. Their results showed high power (32,000 W/kg) and stable cycling performance (85% capacity retention for 700 cycles). Wang et al. [76] proposed a polyimide (i.e., PNFE) as an ARLB anode for its passivated HER activity and reversibility for Li storage. The ARLB consisting of PNFE/CNT anode and LiMn2O4 cathode displayed extraordinary energy density of 76.1 Wh/kg and long cycle life with 65.5% capacity retention after 1000 cycles when fast charged/discharged within 5 min. In 2005, Wang and Xia [77] proposed a hybrid electrochemical supercapacitor using activated carbon (AC) anode and LiMn2O4 cathode, combining the advantages of batteries (energy density) and capacitors (long life, rate). The operating principle of such a new concept hybrid cell is similar to that of “rocking chair battery”; the adsorption/desorption of Li ions occurs on the surface of AC electrode while Li ions are deintercalated/intercalated from the framework of the spinel LiMn2O4 electrode. As shown in Fig. 22 , the cell delivered the specific energy of ca. 35 Wh kg−1 (based on the total weight of the active electrode materials) with a sloping voltage profile from 0.8 to 1.8 V, and displayed an outstanding cycling stability with less than 5% capacity loss after 20,000 charge/discharge cycles at 10 C rate. In 2018, Wang et al. showed the application of olivine FePO4 and amorphous FePO4•2H2O as anode materials for ARLB [78]. As shown in Fig. 23 , the FePO4•2H2O and FePO4 materials can deliver 82 and 163 mAh g−1, respectively, while FePO4 has higher voltage platform which can avoid hydrogen evolution. The full cell using amorphous FePO4•2H2O anode maintained 92% capacity after 500 cycles at a current rate of 0.2 C. 3 Electrolytes of ALIB systems As part of efforts to enhance the electrochemical performance of ALIB systems, the influence of electrolytes has been given much attention alongside the optimization of both anode and cathode materials. Aqueous electrolytes display an order of magnitude higher ionic conductivity than non-aqueous electrolytes in a given concentration, making it possible to achieve high power storage systems [3]. The liquid electrolytes are usually obtained by dissolving salt into suitable solvent. As compared to the non-aqueous solvents, water is an attractive solvent due to its safe nature, excellent solvent with both high acceptor and donor numbers. Moreover, varying the concentrations of electrolytes can make a considerable effect on the potential of Li+ insertion/extraction and the stability of electrode materials. 3.1 Diluted and concentrated electrolytes Water can dissolve most salts to form the solvation structure, according to the coexistence of Lewis basicity of its oxygen site and Lewis acidity of its hydrogen site. In diluted electrolytes, the primary and secondary solvation shells typically contain Li+-ion coordinated with six water molecules, due to the availability of largely free water molecules. In general, 1 M Li2SO4 or LiNO3, was considered as the most common electrolyte used for various electrode materials in neutral pH, including LiMn2O4, LiTi2(PO4)3, polymide, and so on [79–81]. However, as mentioned above, some electrode materials are not stable in diluted electrolytes. The electrochemical performance of LiFePO4 electrode in LiNO3 at different concentrations (2, 5 and 9 M) was carried out. It was concluded that the aqueous solution had a small effect on the polarization and voltage lag, since the voltage plateau was enhanced with the increased concentration [29]. In conventional aqueous electrolytes, the LIBs are typically limited to low voltage and energy density due to the narrow thermodynamic stability window (1.23 V) of water. For this regard, researchers have tried to employ concentrated electrolytes to expand the decomposition voltage of water. In 2015, Wang et al. firstly used a “water-in-salt” electrolyte by dissolving lithium bis (trifluoromethane sulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) at extremely high concentration (molality >20 m) in water to form a dense interphase on the anode surface mainly arising from anion reduction [82]. As compared to the previous Li2SO4 or LiNO3, the huge solubility of LiTFSI provided an expanded electrochemical stability window of 3.0 V. They have assembled a full ALIBs based on a model electrochemically (LiMn2O4 and Mo6S8), achieved an open circuit voltage (OCV) of 2.3 V, and reached nearly 100% coulombic efficiency for up to 1000 cycles at low (0.15 C) and high (4.5 C) rates. Subsequently, 21 mol LiTFSI electrolyte was also reported for ALIBs in other electrode materials, including TiO2, TiS2, LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4, LiMn0.8Fe0.2PO4 and polytriphentl-amine (PTPAn) [83–87]. Most recently, Wang et al. disclosed that solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) is the key component that not only formed in nonaqueous electrolytes, but also observed in aqueous media, leading to significant expansion in the electrochemical stability window of aqueous electrolytes from 1.23 V to beyond 4.0 V [88]. Using a combination of in situ/ex situ spectra techniques, they have analyzed the exact chemical compositions of SEI, and demonstrated the decompositions mechanism of TFSI. Meanwhile, it was conclude that how the dissolved O2 and CO2, and water molecule compete in the initial SEI formation. It was revealed that the salt concentration, chemical structure of salt anion, reduction products and their solubilities in aqueous electrolyte are equally contributed to the formation condition of SEI. 3.2 Additive in electrolytes Another essential aspect of poor cycling ability of ALIBs is the fact that some materials easily dissolve in water. However, as mentioned above, vinylene carbonate (VC) as an additive can improve the stability of LiCr0.15Mn1.85O4 electrode in aqueous solution. This indicates that the crystallographic phase responsible for the high-voltage charging remains more stable in the presence of the additive. Similarly, Stojkovic et al. also successfully used the VC additive to enhance the behavior of a Li-intercalation material in an aqueous solution [19]. 4 Current collectors in ALIB systems In aqueous solution, current collectors are usually consisted of nickel mesh, titanium mesh, aluminum or stainless steel. As previously reported, the electrode/electrolyte interface is essential for optimizing the working parameters of the electrochemical reaction, including hydrogen evolution and oxygen evolution. It should be pointed out that the current collectors may suffer some corrosion during the cycling in aqueous electrolyte [89,90]. The corrosion processes can take place on positive and negative electrodes. Moreover, the choice of current collectors depends of the pH of the aqueous electrolyte. Usually, titanium mesh, a very stable material has large overpotential of oxygen evolution, which can used for both cathode and anode. Nickel mesh cannot be used in acidic media, since the Ni can react with the high concentration of H+, and it cannot be considered as cathode in aqueous solution due to the low oxidation potential of Ni and Ni2+ either. Recently, Wojciechowski et al. found that stainless steel working in 6 M KOH and 1 M KOH has the lowest corrosion potential, and the corrosion potential increases with decreasing pH value [91]. This is caused by the high concentration of OH ions which behave as catalysts for the dissolution of steel components. 5 Challenges and outlooks In terms of sustainability, rechargeable aqueous Li-ion technology is attractive. However, taking into the cost consideration, it is not sure that raise the question of whether aqueous systems can ever be made cheaper than non-aqueous systems, in terms of the cost per kilowatt hour of stored energy. As mentioned above, various side reactions are involved in the electrode reactions of insertion compounds in aqueous solutions, resulting in a reduced reversibility of the cells. The relatively lower energy density due to the limited operating voltage of H2O (≈1.2 V) compared to that of organic electrolyte systems is still the main challenge. Moreover, it is hard to find the perfect electrode materials due to the fact that some materials easily dissolve in water. A shift from a non-aqueous system to an aqueous system may produce a positive effect on the environment and lower the price of the battery, especially large-scale batteries which are required in hybrid and electric vehicles. Among various electrode materials, spinel LiMn2O4 cathode and LiTi2(PO4)3 are the most common candidates for ALIB. Our group has tried to assemble aqueous LiTi2(PO4)3 /LiMn2O4 battery with high power and energy density [11]. The cell delivers a capacity of 40 mAh g−1 and a specific energy of 60 Wh kg−1 with an out-voltage of 1.5 V. After 200 cycles, it can still display an excellent cycling stability with a capacity retention of 82%. However, there is still a long way to go before the practical application of ARLB due to the low specific capacity and limited output voltage, which is currently the most significant challenge. 5.1 H2/O2 evolution reactions from aqueous electrolyte In general, many materials of low and high voltage can be used in the traditional organic lithium batteries. However, in aqueous electrolyte, the electrochemical stability window of the electrolyte is limited to 1.23 V without the effect of over-potential. The insert/extraction reaction should be occur within the water stability window. Moreover, many electrode materials used in organic electrolyte that are not stable in aqueous electrolyte due to the dissolution of electrode in water and side reaction with H2O and O2 in an electrolyte. For example, many vanadium-based compounds, especially the V5+ species can hardly exist in the aqueous electrolyte. Recently, Suo et al. reported extending the operation window of aqueous electrolytes to 3 V via a highly concentrated “water-in salt” electrolyte, extremely decreasing the content of water in electrolyte and providing different strategies to suppress H2/O2 evolution reaction and potentially resulting in a significant enlightenment in ALIBs. However, the high cost of LTFSI electrolyte used in current ALIBs is a restraining factor for their commercialization. 5.2 Proton co-intercalation in parallel with lithium intercalation In aqueous electrolyte, protons may be co-intercalated into the electrode materials parallel to the intercalation of lithium ions, which has been observed in layered structured materials such as LiCoO2 and MnO2 [92–94]. The proton intercalation is related to the crystal structure and the pH of the electrolyte. For example, layered LiCoO2 and LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3O2 contain significant numbers of protons in the lattice during deep lithium extraction with a low pH electrolyte, and the stable lithium deinsertion/insertion was produced until pH over 9. One common strategy is modulating the potential for proton intercalation through adjusting the pH of the electrolyte. Apparently, it is desired to develop the appropriate electrode materials with minimal proton deinsertion/insertion, neutral aqueous electrolytes (pH 7), which can be beneficial to the further ALIBs. In order to achieve superior performance with long cycling life in aqueous electrolyte, it is advisable for us to choose suitable electrode materials and electrolyte solution and control the pH and removing the solved oxygen, and optimize the battery assembly technologies. In addition, recent work have found that using Li metal as anode in the aqueous environment is possible when using dual electrolyte, this improvement can overcome the limited energy density of ALIB. Power Sour. 223 2013 56 61 Duan Bin received his M.S. degree in the College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials Science of Soochow University in 2016. Now he is working toward a Ph.D. degree in Department of Chemistry, Fudan University. His current research is focused on energy-storage materials and aqueous rechargeable batteries. Yunping Wen is currently educated in Fudan University for her Master degree in physical chemistry. She received a B.S. degree from Hubei University in 2015. Her research is focused on the application of electrochemical functional nano-materials in aqueous lithium-ion batteries. Dr. Yonggang Wang received his Ph.D. in Physical Chemistry from Fudan University in 2007. From 2007 to 2011, he worked as a Post-doctoral Research Associate at the National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST), Japan. He is currently a full professor at the Department of Chemistry at Fudan University, China. His research interests include electrochemical functional materials and their application in lithium-ion batteries, metal-air batteries, aqueous batteries, supercapacitors, and fuel cells. Dr. Yongyao Xia is a professor in the Department of Chemistry and Institute of New Energy of Fudan University. He received a Bachelor of Science degree from the Chemistry Department of Zhejiang Normal University in 1987 and a Master of Science degree in Electrochemistry from the Chemistry Department of Jilin University in 1990. He received a PhD degree in Energy-Related-Material Science in Saga University, Japan in 1997. His research interests involve advanced materials and technologies for energy storage and conversion devices, e.g., lithium-ion batteries, sodium-ion batteries, electrochemical supercapacitors, lithium-air, lithium-sulfur batteries etc.

coredata.dc:description: To meet the growing energy demands, it is urgent for us to construct grid-scale energy storage system than can connect sustainable energy resources. Aqueous Li-ion batteries (ALIBs) have been widely investigated to become the most promising stationary power sources for sustainable energy such as wind and solar power. It is believed that advantages of ALIBs will overcome the limitations of the traditional organic lithium battery in virtue of the safety and environmentally friendly aqueous electrolyte. In the past decades, plentiful works have been devoted to enhance the performance of different types of ALIBs. In this review, we discuss the development of cathode, anode and electrolyte for acquiring the desired electrochemical performance of ALIBs. Also, the main challenges and outlook in this field are briefly discussed.
